    KLIFS: A Knowledge-Based Structural Database To Navigate Kinase–Ligand Interaction Space

    • Oscar P. J. van Linden
      • , 
    • Albert J. Kooistra
      • , 
    • Rob Leurs
      • , 
    • Iwan J. P. de Esch
      • , and 
    • Chris de Graaf*
    View Author Information
    Division of Medicinal Chemistry, Faculty of Sciences, Amsterdam Institute for Molecules, Medicines and Systems (AIMMS), VU University Amsterdam, De Boelelaan 1083, 1081 HV Amsterdam, The Netherlands
    *Phone: +31-20598-7553. E-mail: [email protected]
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2014, 57, 2, 249–277
    Publication Date (Web):August 13, 2013

    Publication History

    • Received14 March 2013
    • Published online20 September 2013
    • Published inissue 23 January 2014
    https://doi.org/10.1021/jm400378w

    SUBJECTS:
    • Binding modes,
    • Peptides and proteins,
    • Ligands,
    • Crystal structure,
    • Inhibitors
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Protein kinases regulate the majority of signal transduction pathways in cells and have become important targets for the development of designer drugs. We present a systematic analysis of kinase–ligand interactions in all regions of the catalytic cleft of all 1252 human kinase–ligand cocrystal structures present in the Protein Data Bank (PDB). The kinase–ligand interaction fingerprints and structure database (KLIFS) contains a consistent alignment of 85 kinase ligand binding site residues that enables the identification of family specific interaction features and classification of ligands according to their binding modes. We illustrate how systematic mining of kinase–ligand interaction space gives new insights into how conserved and selective kinase interaction hot spots can accommodate the large diversity of chemical scaffolds in kinase ligands. These analyses lead to an improved understanding of the structural requirements of kinase binding that will be useful in ligand discovery and design studies.

    1 Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Protein kinases are enzymes that catalyze the transfer of the γ-phosphate moiety of ATP to the hydroxyl groups of tyrosine, serine, or threonine residues of their substrates.(1) The large family of kinase proteins plays an important role in key signal transduction pathways, and kinases have therefore become drug targets of great interest in the past 2 decades.(2-4) Currently, 518 protein kinases are known to be encoded in the human genome and are divided into so-called conventional and atypical protein kinases. The conventional protein kinases consist of the largest group and, based on their sequence similarity in the catalytic domain, are subclassified into eight major groups, namely, AGC, CAMK, CK1, CMGC, STE, TK, TKL, and other.(5) In Table 1 an overview of the number of families, subfamilies, and kinases is given. The atypical protein kinases (15 families, not shown) have little or no sequence similarity to the members of the protein kinase superfamily.
    Table 1. Overview of the Number of Families, Subfamilies, and Kinases in Each Group of the Conventional Human Protein Kinases
    groupahuman kinases
    AGC63
    CAMK74
    CK112
    CMGC61
    STE47
    TK90
    TKL43
    other88
    a

    The eight major groups are AGC (PKA, PKG, and PKC containing families), CAMK (calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase), CK1 (casein kinase 1), CMGC (CDK, MAPK, GSK3, and CLK containing families), STE (homologues of yeast sterile 7, sterile 11, sterile 20 kinases), TK (tyrosine kinase), TKL (tyrosine kinase-like), other (protein kinases that do not fit any of the major groups). A graphical representation of the human kinome tree is presented in Figure 4B.

    Deregulation of protein kinase function is a key feature in several pathophysiological processes, making protein kinases import targets for pharmaceutical intervention in a number of therapeutic areas,(6) including oncology,(2) neurology,(7) immunology,(8) cardiology,(9) and infectious disease.(10) Small molecule kinase inhibitors have been developed, and a number of kinase inhibiting chemical entities have successfully entered the market for the treatment of patients in several therapeutic areas (Figure 1).(11-29)

    1.1 Kinase Ligand Binding Sites

    The kinase domain consists of a C-terminal domain and a N-terminal domain that are connected via a hinge (Figure 2A).(30) ATP hydrogen-bonds to the backbone of the hinge, and the vast majority of inhibitors also hydrogen-bond to this region. The N-terminal domain largely consists of β-sheets, while the C-terminal domain is built up mostly by α helices. Important structural features of the kinase domain are the G-rich loop (glycine-rich loop, g.l in Figure 2), the gatekeeper residue (aaGK.45 preceding the hinge region), the αC-helix in the N-terminal domain, the conserved lysine residue (KIII.17 in β-sheet III) which forms a salt bridge with the conserved glutamate residue EαC.24 in the αC-helix and the DFGxDFG.81-83 motif.(30) The current analysis focuses on the catalytic cleft located between the N-terminal lobe and C-terminal lobe, which contains the ATP binding site and is the major focus of kinase inhibitor development. This region can be divided into a front cleft (containing the ATP binding site), gate area, and back cleft (Figure 2A).(30) In Figure 3 an overview of different pockets that are present in the front and back clefts are schematically presented.
    Most kinase inhibitors developed so far bind in the adenine pocket (AP), which is located in the front cleft (Figure 2A, 3) and make one to three hydrogen-bond interactions to residues 46 and 48 of the hinge region.(31) A strategy to increase the potency and selectivity of kinase inhibitors is to design and synthesize molecules that target hydrophobic pockets in the back cleft (Figure 2A, 3).(30) A complementary design approach is to accommodate polar inhibitor–kinase interactions with conserved parts in the kinase domain (e.g., hinge region in the front cleft, DFG-motif and KIII.17 in the gate area, and EαC.24 in the back cleft). Both strategies will be discussed in sections 3–6. Within the catalytic cleft several selectivity pockets can be addressed by small molecule inhibitors.(30, 32) In the front cleft, a pocket located between the solvent exposed loop (linker) and the DFG-motif (xDFG) may be present, termed front pocket I (FP-I). A second pocket, located between the G-rich loop (g.l.) and β-sheet III, is termed front pocket II (FP-II). In the back cleft multiple pockets exist (BP-I, BP-II, BP-III, BP-IV, BP-V, as defined by Liao),(30) which differ in size depending on the activation state of the kinase (e.g., DFG-in or -out, αC-helix-in or -out).(30) A conformational change of the DFG-motif (positions 81–83, Figure 2A, 3) from the “in” to the “out” conformation results in the formation of an inactive state of the kinase. This DFG-flip opens up the larger hydrophobic region in the back cleft, which was first demonstrated by the development of 6 (imatinib, Figure 1).(17) Stabilization of specific DFG conformations (section 5) has been used as a successful kinase inhibitor design strategy (sections 3–6).(2, 30, 33) The ease of access to the back cleft is determined by the size of the gatekeeper (GK), a residue preceding the hinge region and located on β-sheet V (position 45, Figure 2A).(34) Incorporation of functional groups that can selectively target the GK residue(s) of the desired kinase(s) and/or make unfavorable interactions with the region around the GK of undesired kinase targets has been a successful approach in kinase inhibitor design (section 3.2).
    Different types of kinase inhibitors can be defined: type I inhibitors that bind to the active DFG-in conformation, type II inhibitors that bind to the inactive DFG-out conformation, type I1/2 inhibitors that bind in the DFG-in conformation but extend into the back pockets, type III inhibitors that form ternary complexes with the kinase and ATP, allosteric type IV inhibitors that target protein kinases distal to the ATP binding pocket, and type V bisubstrate and bivalent inhibitors that combine different inhibitor classes.(35) However, these types I–V classifications do not allow proper and consistent classification of the diversity in kinase ligand binding modes observed in kinase crystal structures and do not account for the many different combinations of subpockets that inhibitors can address in different kinase conformations.
    Back pocket I (BP-I) is located in the gate area between residues of the xDFG-motif, β-sheets III and V, conserved LysIII.17, and αC-helix (Figure 3). BP-I can be divided into two subpockets. BP-I-B is a larger pocket that is located in the center of the gate area through which access to other back pockets is facilitated. The smaller BP-I-A is located at the top of the gate area and is formed by residues of β-sheets III and V, conserved LysIII.17, and αC-helix. BP-I-A and BP-I-B are available in both DFG-in and DFG-out kinases and can be targeted by type I and type II inhibitors. Between the DFG-motif and αC-helix a pocket may exist, while the kinase is in a DFG-in fashion, termed back pocket II-in (BP-II-in). Outward shifting of the αC-helix (αC-out), while the kinase is in a DFG-in fashion, results in the formation of a larger back pocket II-in, termed back pocket II-A-in (BP-II-A-in). This pocket consists of residues of the DFG-motif, αC-helix, back loop (b.l.), and β-sheets IV and V.
    Significant enlargement of BP-II-in occurs upon a DFG-flip toward a DFG-out kinase. The resulting pocket is termed back pocket II-out (BP-II-out). Between αC-helix and β-sheet IV, a back pocket may exist in both DFG-in and DFG-out kinases, termed BP-II-B. Back pocket III (BP-III) is a pocket that is accessible only in the DFG-out form of the kinase. The pocket is located in the basement of BP-II-out, between the DFG-out-motif, back loop (b.l.), αC- and αE-helix, β-sheet VI, and conserved histidine 68 residue of HRD motif in the catalytic loop (c.l). Two partially hydrophobic back pockets (BP-IV and -V) are located between the αC-helix, DFG(-out) motif, β-sheet VI, catalytic loop (c.l.), and the activation loop (a.l.). These pockets are partially solvent exposed.
    The high structural similarity in the kinase domains and the utilization of conserved kinase–ligand interactions make it difficult to design selective kinase inhibitors.(30, 36, 37) In addition, kinase domains are flexible protein structures and ligand induced conformational changes are commonly observed, which raise both challenges and opportunities for rational design of novel inhibitors.(33) The focus on the kinase front cleft in kinase ligand design has resulted in the discovery of a large number of chemically diverse heteroaromatic scaffolds that can bind the kinase hinge region.(34, 38) The design and/or optimization of many kinase ligands has been supported by X-ray crystallography and structure-based ligand design approaches (e.g., refs 39−42). As a result, kinases are one of most represented protein families in the Protein Data Bank (PDB).(-43, 44) The sheer numbers and diversity of ligand bound kinase structures make this protein class a particularly interesting system to investigate the details of molecular interactions using chemogenomics approaches.(45-47) Identification of the molecular determinants of kinase–ligand interactions will be beneficial for the design of ligands with specific selectivity profiles(48) and discovery of ligands for novel kinase targets.(3)

    1.2 Structure-Based Mining of Kinase–Ligand Interaction Space

    Classification of kinase–ligand cocrystal structures and analysis of kinase–ligand interaction patterns have been reported, but these studies have focused on specific interaction features, including conserved hinge backbone interactions,(34) utilization of hydrophobic back pockets,(30) stabilization of inactivated DFG-out forms,(32) interactions of inhibitors with the P-loop,(49) and hydrogen bonding of ligands with the DFG-motif and EαC.24 in DFG-in or DFG-out kinases.(50) Previous kinase–ligand interaction analyses were furthermore based on relatively small crystal structure subsets (of 50–600 complexes) compared to the total number of 1252 ligand-bound kinase domain crystal structures currently available in the Protein Data Bank.(43) Ghose et al.(34) performed an analysis on 409 kinase–inhibitor complexes from the PDB. The authors focused on the kinase hinge region and categorized the inhibitors in ligand core structures that bind to the kinase hinge by making one, two, or three hydrogen bond interactions. McGregor et al.(31) aligned 220 small molecule protein kinase inhibitor complexes and presented a pharmacophore map of the inhibitors in the adenine binding site. Deng et al.(51) used structural interaction fingerprints for the analysis of 89 kinase–inhibitor crystal structures from the PDB and were able to reveal similarities and diversity between small molecule binding interactions of 54 small molecule kinase ligands. A structural comparison of protein kinase ATP-binding sites for the functional classification of the protein kinase family has been performed by Kinnings et al.(52) In a set of 354 kinase crystal structures they were able to detect subtle differences in binding site conformation within different protein kinases, such as differences in activation states and ligand-induced conformational changes.(52) Patel and Doerksen performed analyses of protein conformational variability and interactions of ligands with 11 P-loop residues using a database of 607 ligand bound human kinase crystal structures.(49) Recently, Vidović et al.(53) described the reshuffling of fragments of 936 cocrystallized ATP-competitive kinase inhibitors and generated ∼150 000 new ligand structures after considering both receptor-based similarity constraints and ligand-based filters.
    Databases annotating kinase sequences and phylogenetic classification,(5, 54-56) structures,(55, 57, 58) pathways,(59-61) and inhibitors(57, 62) are widely available. While some are commercial, others are open access. For example, the sc-PDB, a database of druggable binding sites in proteins, contains 1148 kinase binding sites that are clustered and aligned according to protein kinase subtype.(44, 63) So far, however, a comprehensive and systematic structure-based analysis that describes kinase–ligand interaction features in all different regions of the kinase ligand binding site is lacking. In the current study we present the first systematic and consistent analysis of kinase–ligand interaction patterns in all regions of the catalytic site of all currently available human kinase crystal structures. For this extensive analysis of the kinase–ligand interactome, we have constructed a database of all 1252 aligned human kinase–ligand cocrystal structures present in the Protein Data Bank (www.pdb.org)(43) and used molecular interaction fingerprints (IFP)(64, 65) to map the kinase–ligand interactions (Figures 4 and 5). The kinase–ligand interaction fingerprints and structure database (KLIFS, Figure 4A) contains the most up to date, comprehensive, and freely available overview of human kinase structures containing the catalytic domain, comprising 1734 crystal structures (covering 190 different kinases) in contrast to, for example, the Kinase SARfari (version 5.00),(57) which contains ∼630 crystal structures of human kinases (covering ∼105 different kinases). The amount of structures in the KLIFS database and the fact that it is freely available already make it different from other structural kinase databases. However, it especially differs in the setup and annotation of all the crystal structures. The superposition of all structures, the extraction of the binding pockets, dissection of the full crystal structure, annotation of the DFG-in, -out, and -out-like conformation, and the generated interaction profiles (IFP) make it especially suitable for ligand design and structure-based optimization. The consistent manner of the database creation allows for an easy (visual) comparison of multiple structures, cocrystallized inhibitors, and their interactions profiles. When used in combination with docking, the overlay of ligand binding poses of a compound in multiple kinases in combination with their aligned pockets can give insight into the next steps for ligand optimization in order to obtain more (or less) selective compounds. The observed interaction patterns for each part of the catalytic cleft and the corresponding inhibitor (sub)structures provide clues for scaffold hopping and targeting of new/extra interactions. The final KLIFS database contains a consistent 3D alignment and numbering of the 85 kinase ligand binding site residues (Figure 2B) with their corresponding ligand structures and interaction fingerprint bit-strings. The same residue numbering scheme is consistently used throughout the manuscript:

    • [amino acid][kinase region in Figure 2A].[residue number in Figure 2B]

    (e.g., KIII.17, the conserved lysine residue in β sheet III, residue number 17). This enables the identification of family- or group-specific interaction features and classification of ligands according to their binding modes. Our binding mode analysis focused on the following kinase–ligand interaction features:
    1.

    binding site topology and amino acid sequence analysis (Figure 2B) for the identification of conserved and diverse regions in the kinase ligand binding site (Table 2);

    2.

    hydrogen-bond interaction patterns at the hinge region (residues 46–48, Figure 2A);

    3.

    polar interactions with conserved residues KIII.17, EαC.24, and the DFG-motif (residues 81–83, Figure 2A);

    4.

    hydrophobic contacts in the catalytic cleft and hydrophobic back pockets (Figure 2A);

    5.

    types of interactions made to the gatekeeper residue number 45 (Figure 2A);

    6.

    kinase flexibility, including conformation of the DFG-motif, position of α-helix C (Figure 2A).

    The 85 amino acids included in our analysis cover the binding modes and interactions of types I, I1/2,(50) II, and III (e.g., MEK) inhibitors. However, the MEK specific pocket is partly built up by an α-helix that is present in the activation loop of MEK kinases.(66) The amino acids that build up this specific α-helix were omitted in the alignment protocol and pocket selection (see Supporting Information). We illustrate how systematic mining of kinase–ligand interaction space can give insights into how conserved and selective kinase interaction hot spots in the different regions of the kinase binding site can accommodate the large diversity of chemical scaffolds observed in kinase ligands.

    2 Kinase–Ligand Complexes

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    2.1 Construction Database of Structurally Aligned Human Kinase–Ligand Complexes

    For the systematic analysis of the available human kinase crystal structures from the PDB, we designed a customized structural alignment protocol (Figure 4A). This robust alignment enabled large-scale comparison of the kinase structures for the detection of structural similarities and differences within the kinase structures. By use of the Uniprot accession number, these structures were annotated and grouped into kinase classes (Figure 4B). Non-kinase-domain-containing structures were discarded, which resulted in a total of 1734 kinase domain structures, of which 1257 contained a ligand, 234 are apo-structures, and 242 are ATP/ADP/staurosporine or ATP/staurosporine-analogue containing structures. The structures cover 190 unique kinases, of which 129 have structures containing a ligand. All 1734 structures were split into different chains and alternative locations, resulting in a total number of 3391 unique chains/alternative locations (see Supporting Information). In total 2346 of these chains were ligand-bound structures, of which 1252 (five problematic complexes were discarded; see Supporting Information) were unique ligand–protein chains with an IFP that were used for further analysis (Figure 4B). The extracted structures were then aligned to a specifically constructed kinase-template set. This set contains 24 structures of kinases representative of all eight eukaryotic protein kinase (ePK) groups (three structures per group), which were manually aligned with a focus on known conserved patterns (see Supporting Information Table S2). After that, the structures were superimposed onto the template after which the pocket and ligand were extracted from the complex. Details about this procedure are described in the Supporting Information. The construction of the KLIFS database has resulted in an updatable framework containing a large number of superimposed crystal structures. The database enables extensive analysis of class- and family-specific features and facilitates future recognition of kinase specific elements because of the continued addition of new crystal structures.

    2.2 Mining the KLIFS Database: Kinase–Ligand Binding Mode Classification

    Interaction fingerprint(64) analysis was conducted to describe the binding mode of the ligands in the complexes. An example of the (condensed) IFP strings of two inhibitors is shown in Figure 4C. For each amino acid in the catalytic cleft, seven types of protein–ligand interactions are determined. The presence of a certain type of interaction results in the type-setting of a “1” in the bit-string; otherwise a “0” is used to indicate the absence of the interaction. The following seven types of interactions are summarized in one bit-string; bit 1 = hydrophobic contact (HYD); bit 2 = face to face aromatic interactions (F–F); bit 3 = face to edge aromatic interactions (F–E); bit 4 = protein H-bond donor (DON); bit 5 = protein H-bond acceptor (ACC); bit 6 = protein cationic interactions (ION+), and bit 7 = protein anionic interactions (ION–). From Figure 4C it is apparent that the binding mode of the inhibitor that is described by the top IFP string is different from the binding mode of the inhibitor that is described by the lower IFP string. The upper inhibitor is a front cleft binder, since no hydrophobic contacts are made with residues in the back cleft area. The lower inhibitor, however, extends into the kinase back cleft as indicated by the hydrophobic contacts made to the back cleft amino acids. Furthermore, this inhibitor forms a hydrogen bond with the conserved EαC.24 by donating a hydrogen to this amino acid. By use of the generated IFP strings, the inhibitors are classified based on their location in the catalytic cleft. Searching for specific IFP bit combinations enables the extraction of inhibitors that target specific selectivity pockets in the kinases or form specific hydrogen bond interactions. An example describing the different binding modes of four marketed kinase inhibitors is presented in Figure 5. An overview of all the interactions made by the 1252 inhibitors in the three main areas of the catalytic cleft (front cleft, gate area, and back cleft) is shown in Table 3. Amino acids with zero interactions are not shown in the table.

    2.3 Sequence Conservation and Variability in Kinase Ligand Binding Cavities

    In the catalytic cleft, conserved residues and motifs are present. For example, the G-rich loop, which contains a conserved GxGxxG motif, is present (g.l.4, g.l.6, and g.l.9, respectively, Figure 2), where position 8 is often a phenylalanine (F) or tyrosine (Y) residue (Table 2). In β-sheet III, a highly conserved lysine residue (KIII.17) is present, which forms a salt bridge with a conserved glutamate residue on the αC-helix (EαC.24) in many kinase structures. On the catalytic loop, the HRD triad (c.l.68–70) and an asparagine residue at position 75 (c.l.75) are clearly present. Another highly conserved motif is the DFG-motif (xDFG.80–83). Table 2 gives an overview of the conserved residues and motifs in the catalytic clefts of the aligned human ligand bound kinase structures.
    Table 2. Conserved Residues (%) in Catalytic Cleft of Ligand Bound Crystal Structures
    residue/motiflocationpositionconservation (%)
    GxGxxGfront cleftg.l.4/g.l.6/g.l.998/100/81
    F (Y)front cleftg.l.868 (19)
    Vfront cleftII.1194
    VAfront cleftIII.14/III.1564/96
    HRDfront cleft (DFG-in)/back cleft (DFG-out)ac.l.68–7090/88/99
    K (A)front cleftc.l.7271 (26)
    Nfront cleftc.l.7597
    M/T/F/L/Vgate areaV.4533/20/19/18/5
    Kgate areaIII.17100
    V/I/L/Tgate areab.l.3653/24/9/7
    A/S/G/T/Cgate areaxDFG.8033/13/12/12/9
    DFGgate areaxDFG.81–8399/88/98
    Eback cleftαC.2499
    L/M/Y/Hback cleftαC.2853/27/7/3
    a

    The HRD motif is part of the front cleft in DFG-in kinases and part of the back cleft in DFG-out kinases.

    3 Analysis of Kinase–Ligand Interactions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Figure 5 gives an overview of the binding modes of four approved kinase inhibitors and illustrates the different binding locations and interaction patterns. The c-MET inhibitor 14 (crizotinib, Figure 5A, 2wgj)(70) is a front cleft binder and makes polar interactions solely to the hinge region while probing into a selectivity pocket in the front cleft (FP-I) with the halogen substituted phenyl ring. Inhibitor 15 (dasatinib) extends into the kinase gate area region of ABL1 and is involved in hydrogen bonding with the gatekeeper (GK) residue TV.45 (Figure 5B, 2gqg).(71) The phenyl ring of 15 binds in the gate area in a selectivity pocket BP-I-B, while the chlorine atom of 15 probes up into a smaller selectivity pocket (BP-I-A, Figure 3A, Table 5). The EGFR inhibitor 5 (lapatinib, Figure 5C, 1xkk)(18) extends further into the back cleft, while the kinase is in a DFG-in fashion. The chlorine atom of 5 occupies BP-I-A. The central phenyl ring occupies BP-I-B, and the right-most phenyl ring occupies BP-II-A-in (Table 5). The ABL1 inhibitor 7 (nilotinib, Figure 5D, 3cs9)(72) binds a DFG-out conformation of the protein and probes extra selectivity pockets in the back cleft, including BP-I-A (methyl moiety), BP-1-B (central phenyl ring), BP-II-out (right-most phenyl ring), BP-III (CF3 moiety), and BP-IV (imidazole ring). By use of the IFP patterns of the 1252 aligned kinase–ligand complexes (Table 3), the inhibitors were divided into front cleft and back cleft binders (Figure 4). The current analysis provides an overview of inhibitors binding in the different selectivity pockets in the front and back clefts. For the group of front cleft binders, hydrogen bond interaction combinations that are used to increase ligand-binding potency are described.
    Table 3. IFP Analysis on the 1252 Aligned Ligand Bound Structuresa
    Table a

    The table is divided in a front cleft, back cleft and gate area. The total number of different interaction types (HYD, F–F, F–E, DON, ACC, ION+, ION–) for each residue (AA, see Figure 2B for residue numbering) of the binding pocket is presented. Amino acids with zero interactions are not shown. Abbreviations: AA, amino acid number; HYD, hydrophobic contacts; F–F, face to face aromatic interactions; F–E, face to edge aromatic interactions; DON, protein H-bond donor; ACC, protein H-bond acceptor; ION+, protein cationic interactions; ION–, protein anionic interactions.

    3.1 H-Bond Interaction Patterns with the Hinge

    H-bond interactions with the hinge region are highly conserved interactions that are observed in >88% of all human kinase–ligand cocrystal structures (Table 3, Table 4). The backbone amide nitrogen atom of aahinge.48 donates a H-bond to the ligand in over 86% of the kinase structures (Table 4, entry 2), while the backbone carbonyl oxygen atoms of aahinge.46 and/or aahinge.48 accept a H-bond from the ligand in >35% of the cases (Table 4, entries 1 and 3). There are, however, different ways in which ligands can form H-bond interactions with the backbone oxygen atom of aahinge.46 and/or backbone nitrogen atom and/or oxygen atom of aahinge.48 (Table 4). In general four different binding modes with the hinge region can be distinguished:

    (1) Three H-Bond Interactions with the Hinge

    CDK2 inhibitor 19 (Table 5, 2vtl)(73) illustrates how ligands can fully utilize the hydrogen bonding capacity of the kinase hinge backbone region. The 1H-pyrazole-3-carboxamide group can simultaneously accept an H-bond from aahinge.48 while donating H-bonds to aahinge.46 and aahinge.48. Other examples of chemical scaffolds that can facilitate three H-bond interactions with the hinge are 9H-purin-2-amine (e.g., 1e1v),(74) 2H-pyrazolo[4,3-d]pyrimidin-7-amine (e.g., 3pj8),(75) and 1H-indazol-3-amine (e.g., 3qd4).(76) Thirteen percent of the structures contain a ligand that forms three hydrogen bonds with the hinge region (Table 4, entry 10).

    (2) Two H-Bond Interactions with the Hinge Backbone

    The number of inhibitors that binds via two hydrogen bonds does this predominantly in a donor–acceptor fashion, either by interacting with aahinge.48 and aahinge.46 simultaneously (Table 4, entry 8, e.g., inhibitor 14 in Figure 5A) or by interacting with aahinge.48 alone (Table 4, entry 7, e.g., inhibitor 15 in Figure 5B). Examples of groups that can form H-bonds with aahinge.48 and aahinge.46 at the same time are amino pyrimidines (e.g., 4dfl),(77) 9H-purin-6-amines (e.g., 3rwp),(78) indazoles (e.g., 3v8s),(79) thieno[3,2-c]pyridin-4-amines (e.g., 3tjc),(80) or phenols (e.g., 3p0m).(81) Chemical scaffolds that can simultaneously accept and donate H-bonds with aahinge.48 are amino pyrimidines (e.g., 4e93),(82) pyrazolo[1,5-a]pyrimidin-7-amines (e.g., 2vts),(73) thiazolo[5,4-b]pyridin-2-amines (e.g., 4dbn),(83) 3,4-dihydro-1,8-naphthyridin-2(1H)-ones (e.g., 3q96),(84) or more complex ring systems like N-(pyrimidin-4-yl)thiazol-2-amines (as exemplified by the binding mode of 15 with Abl, Figure 5B).(70) Recently a new pyrrolo[2,3-d]thiazole scaffold was disclosed, which has been cocrystallized with focal adhesion kinase (FAK, 3pxk).(85)

    (3) One Single H-Bond Interaction with the Hinge Backbone

    More than a quarter of the inhibitors that form a single hydrogen bond with the hinge do so with the amide nitrogen atom of aahinge.48, as illustrated by the binding mode of 5 (Table 4, entry 5, Figure 5C). Other examples of such scaffolds include imidazo[1,2-b]pyridazines (e.g., 4dym),(86) quinolines (e.g., 3ue4),(87) isoquinolines (e.g., 3tku),(88) but also pyrrolo[2,1-f][1,2,4]triazine C6-ketones (e.g., 3s4q)(89) and 2,2-dimethylbenzo[d][1,3]dioxoles (e.g., 3raw).(90) Merely 2% of the inhibitors form a single hydrogen bond by donating a hydrogen to the backbone carbonyl oxygen of aahinge.46 (Table 4, entry 6, e.g., 3t9i,(91)3c4e,(92)3dcv(93)) or aahinge.48 (Table 4, entry 4, e.g., 2ycs(94)).

    (4) No or Alternative Interactions with Hinge Region

    In addition to H-bond patterns presented in Table 4, kinase inhibitors can adopt alternative binding modes with the hinge backbone. The 6,7-dichloroindoline moiety of the CLK3 inhibitor (E)-ethyl 3-(2-amino-1-cyanovinyl)-6,7-dichloro-1-methyl-1H-indole-2-carboxylate (20, Supporting Information Figure S1), for example, forms only a single halogen bond with the aahinge.46 carbonyl oxygen (2wu7),(95) while the 4,5,6,7-tetrabromo-1H-benzo[d][1,2,3]triazole moiety of the inhibitor 3-(4,5,6,7-tetrabromo-1H-benzotriazol-1-yl)propan-1-ol (21, Supporting Information Figure S1) (3ofm)(96) forms two halogen bonds(96) with the hinge backbone carbonyl oxygen atoms of aahinge.48 and aahinge.46 in CK2. In addition to H-bonds and halogen bonds, kinase–ligand interactions with the hinge can be mediated by CH–O hydrogen bonds with backbone carbonyl atoms,(97) as exemplified by the binding mode of 4 (bosutinib, Figure 8B, 3ue4)(98) in ABL1 and 5 (Figure 5C, 1xkk)(18) in EGFR. The quinoline C-2 CH of 4 and the quinazoline C-2 CH of 5 not only do accept a H-bond from the backbone amide nitrogen of Mhinge.48 but also form a CH H-bond with the carbonyl oxygen of Qhinge.46 and Ehinge.46, respectively (Figure 5C, Figure 8B). However, these CH–O bonds are not identified as H-bond interactions with the current IFP analysis method.(61) An example of this is inhibitor 22, which makes two CH–O bonds to the kinase hinge region of Pim1 that are not picked up in the IFP analysis (Table 5, 1yi3).(99) An interesting conformational rearrangement, called hinge flip or glycine flip, can occur at the hinge region. The hinge flip involves an approximate 180° flip of the Glinker.49 residue, which rotates the backbone carbonyl oxygen atom of hinge.48 away from the ATP binding site and the backbone NH of Glinker.49 into the ATP binding site.(100) Since only 46 of all 518 kinases have a glycine residue at position aahinge.49 and are therefore able to perform a hinge flip, exploiting the newly introduced H-bond donor can be used by inhibitors to gain selectivity toward these kinases.(101) There are 32 crystal structures of kinase–inhibitor complexes (all p38), in which the inhibitor binds to the flipped hinge region. Examples include structures in DFG-in (e.g., 1m7q),(102) DFG-out-like (e.g., 3hp2),(103) and DFG-out (Table 4, hinge pattern 13, e.g., 1kv2)(104) kinases. An overview of the H-bonding patterns at the hinge region is presented in Table 4. Eleven different combinations of H-bond interactions with aahinge.48 and aahinge.46 were defined using the IFP bit-strings of the kinase–inhibitor complexes. Hinge H-bond interaction pattern 4, for example, specifically identifies the kinase–inhibitor complexes in which the inhibitor only donates an H-bond to aahinge.48 (while no other H-bonds are formed with the hinge region).
    Table 4. Analysis of Kinase–Ligand Hydrogen-Bonding Patterns at the Hinge Region (See Figure 2)
     hinge.48ahinge.46astructures
    hinge H-bond interaction patternacc (C═O)bdon (N-H)cacc (C═O)b% inhibitorsno. inhibitors
    110/10/138481
    20/110/1861077
    30/10/1135442
    4100111
    501028352
    6001115
    711024300
    801121257
    9101<12

    a

    See Figure 2 for residue numbering in the hinge region.

    b

    H-bond interaction between kinase backbone carbonyl oxygen (H-bond acceptor) and ligand H-bond donor.

    c

    H-bond interaction between kinase backbone amide nitrogen (H-bond donor) and ligand H-bond acceptor.

    d

    3.2 Kinase–Ligand Interactions in the Catalytic Cleft

    A schematic overview of binding modes of inhibitors that probe into selectivity pockets in the front cleft (FP-I, FP-II), gate area, and back cleft (BP-I, BP-II, BP-III, BP-IV, BP-V) is presented in Table 5. The PDB entries associated with inhibitors that probe into the presented selectivity pockets are indicated, together with a reference to the figure in which the 3D binding mode is shown. Aromatic face–face/edge interactions are predominantly made in the front cleft, with the aahinge.47. Eight percent of the inhibitors are involved in aromatic interactions with aag.l.8 on the G-loop. Ionic interactions are scarcely present in the kinase–inhibitor complexes. The majority of these types of interactions occur in the solvent exposed part of the kinases at aalinker.52. Typically, solubilizing groups on the kinase inhibitors tend to bind here.

    3.2.1 Front Cleft Binders

    In 799 complexes, compounds were assigned to be front cleft binders, of which 78 were identified as nonhinge binders. These compounds either were not involved in hydrogen bonding with the hinge or interact with the hinge via halogen-bonding or CH-bonding. Interactions of the inhibitors in the front cleft mainly consist of hydrophobic interactions (Table 3). More specifically, 84% of all inhibitors make hydrophobic contacts with amino acids I.3, II.11, III.15, and VII.77 of β-sheets I, II, III, and VII, respectively. These residues are relatively conserved among kinases (Figure 2) and line the so-called “adenine pocket” (AP) that binds ring systems in kinase inhibitors that mimic the adenine ring of ATP.(30) Extensive hydrophobic contacts are also made with the kinase hinge (>89% with aahinge.47).
    Table 5. Schematic Overview of Inhibitor Binding Modes in the Kinase Catalytic Clefta
    Table a

    The hinge amino acids hinge.48 and hinge.46, gatekeeper (GKV.45) and DFG-motif are shown. Subpockets are indicated as colored spheres: AP, gray; FP-1, orange; xI, magenta; BP-I, yellow; BP-II-in (A and B, DFG-in), green; BP-II-out, red; BP-III, cyan; BP-IV, blue; BP-V, blue.

    3.2.2 Hydrogen-Bond Interactions at the Gate Area (GK/KIII.7/xDFG)

    From the compounds that solely bind in the front cleft, 339 compounds make stabilizing hydrogen-bond interactions at the gate area. Hydrogen bonding at the gate area can occur with the side chains of the gatekeeperV.45 and KIII.17 and with the xDFG-motif. When XxDFG.80 is, for example, a Ser of Thr residue, the side chain of this residue acts as a hydrogen-bond donor in 30 structures, as illustrated by the binding mode of inhibitor 23 in complex with PDK1 (Figure 6A, 1uu9).(105) The Erk2 inhibitor 24 is involved in simultaneously hydrogen-bonding with the gatekeeperV.45 and KIII.17 by respectively donating and accepting a hydrogen for hydrogen bonding (Figure 6B, Table 5, 2ojg).(106) The conserved DxDFG.81 residue can act as a hydrogen-bond acceptor via its side chain acid moiety and is involved as an hydrogen-bond acceptor in 107 structures. This is illustrated by the binding mode of 25 in Chk1, which makes hydrogen bonds to DxDFG.81 and KIII.17 (Figure 6C, 3tki).(107) The Nek2 inhibitor 26 makes hydrogen bond interactions to protonated KIII.17 and NH atom of the DxDFG.81 and stabilizes the kinase DFG-out-like conformation of Nek2, without extending into the back cleft (Figure 6D, 2xk4).(108) The conserved DxDFG.81 residue can act as a hydrogen-bond donor via its backbone NH (72 cases), stabilizing both DFG-in and -out-like conformations. FxDFG.82 and GxDFG.83 of the xDFG-motif are not involved in hydrogen bonding interactions with front cleft binders.

    3.2.3 Subpockets in the Front Cleft (FP-I/FP-II)

    Potency and selectivity of inhibitors binding in the front cleft may also be achieved by addressing subpockets in the front cleft. The inhibitor (3Z)-5-[(2,6-dichlorobenzyl)sulfonyl]-3-[(3,5-dimethyl-4-{[(2R)-2-(pyrrolidin-1-ylmethyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl]carbonyl}-1H-pyrrol-2-yl)methylene]-1,3-dihydro-2H-indol-2-one (27, PHA-665752,(109)Supporting Information Figure S1) bound c-MET crystal structure (2wkm, not shown)(70) was used to design inhibitor 14 to more effectively bind in FP-I of c-MET (Figure 5A, Table 5, 2wgj).(70) The 2-aminopyridine core of 14 allowed the 3-benzyloxy group to more efficiently reach FP-I than the 2,6-dichlorophenyl group of 27 (resulting in a better ligand efficiency).(70) FP-I is accommodated not only in c-MET (in 16 structures) but also in AurA, CDK2, JAK2, AKT1, and others (Table 5). In some kinases, FP-I can be considerably deep, while in other kinases FP-I is shallower and accommodates, for example, a halogen atom.
    A combination of fragment-based screening and structure-guided scaffold hopping enabled the discovery of ROCK1 inhibitor 28 that binds into FP-II, another front cleft pocket located in the G-loop (Figure 7A, Table 5, 3v8s).(79) Ligand efficiency (LE) analysis was used to guide the fragment optimization process and indicated that the ethylene linker is the optimal spacer that allows the phenyl group to reach deep in this hydrophobic pocket. FP-II is also occupied in several other kinases, including PDK1, Jak2, AKT1, PKA-C, AurA, and others (Table 5). Moreover, FP-II might also be induced in other kinases because of the relative flexibility of the G-loop.
    Interestingly, there are several kinases that accommodate ligands in both FP-I and FP-II simultaneously, including Akt1, Akt2, Jak2, TBK1, and others (Table 5). Inhibitor 12 (tofacitinib), for example, is a JAK3 inhibitor with an excellent selectivity profile(36) that is approved for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (Figure 7B, Table 5, 3lxk).(27) Inhibitor 12 probes into FP-I with its piperidine C7 methyl group and FP-II with its nitrile group. Computational analysis using Watermap suggested that the C7 methyl and nitrile groups are involved in the displacement of unfavorable water molecules in FP-I and FP-II that might contribute to the binding affinity of 12 toward JAK3 and other JAK isozymes.(27)
    Identification of inhibitors for PKB using a fragment-based approach led to the identification of 29, which was optimized into 30 (Figure 7C).(41) Both fragments were soaked in non-human PKA-PKB chimera crystals (2uw3 and 2uw4, respectively, crystal structures not shown) and optimized into 31 (Figure 7D, 2uw9).(41) This compound probes with the chlorine substituted phenyl ring up into FP-II.

    3.3 Kinase–Ligand Interactions in the Back Cleft

    For inhibitor potency and selectivity, growing inhibitors from the front cleft into the back cleft is a frequently used optimization strategy.(32) In the back cleft a number of hydrophobic subpockets (BP-I, BP-II, BP-III, BP-IV, BP-V) may be available in the kinase(30) that can be addressed by the appropriate substituents. Here we describe to what extent these subpockets are used by inhibitors in the kinase set.

    3.3.1 Back Pocket I (BP-I-A and BP-I-B)

    The gate area connects the front cleft (AP, FP) with the back cleft. Back pocket I-B (BP-I-B) is a large pocket that is located in the center of this gate area that gives access to other back pockets. Back pocket I-A (BP-I-A) is located at the top of the gate area and is formed by residues III.15, III.17, αC.28, V.40, V.41, and the gatekeeper V.45. The accessibility of the smaller BP-I-A pocket is largely dependent on the size of the gatekeeperV.45 residue, and BP-I-A is targeted by both DFG-in and DFG-out inhibitors. Inhibitor 32 (tozasertib) stabilizes ABL1 in the active DFG-in conformation and binds BP-I-B with its apolar cyclopropyl group (Figure 8A, 2f4j).(110) The fact that 32 does not form a H-bond with the gatekeeper explains why 32 (unlike, for example, 6) is also effective against, for example, the ABL1 T315IV.45 mutant.(110) Examples of inhibitors targeting BP-I-A and BP-I-B are the drugs 2 (erlotinib) and 4, as illustrated by the binding mode of 4 in Abl1 (Figure 8B, 3ue4, DFG-out-like).(70) Inhibitor 4 stabilizes the DFG-out-like conformation of Abl1 via face-to-edge π interactions with FxDFG.82 and by completely enveloping gatekeeper TV.45 with both the nitrile group and the 5-methoxy group of the aniline ring. The phenylalanine of the DFG motif FxDFG.82 accounts for 13% of the face–edge interactions in all the complexes. A total number of 162 compounds target BP-I without extending further into the back cleft (Table 5). This binding mode is observed for many different kinase types, including p38, JNK3, EGFR, EphB4, BTK, SRC, and others.
    Cyclization of a hybrid between two pyrrolopyridine fragment ligands of Jak2 resulted in a new kinase inhibitor scaffold that was further optimized by SAR, yielding 33 (Figure 8C, 3kck).(42) Compound 33 penetrates the gate area via BP-I-B and forms two H-bonds with the backbone of FxDFG.82 and side chain of EαC.24, via a para-substituted OH group.(42)

    3.3.2 Back Pocket II: DFG-in (BP-II-in)

    Back pocket II is situated in the back cleft, between the DFG-motif and αC-helix. The size of BP-II depends on the position of the αC-helix and status of the DFG-motif (i.e., -in or -out). Compound 34 in complex with p38α illustrates the probing of the small BP-II in a DFG-in kinase (Figure 9A, 3s4q).(89) The αC-helix is in the active “in” position in this structure. Cyclopropyl or heterocyclic amide substituents allow H-bond interactions between the amide group and EC.24 in the αC-helix and are sterically compatible with the relatively small BP-II in p38-DFG-in.(89)
    Our analysis identified 39 structures with front cleft binding compounds targeting BP-II in DFG-in kinases, including p38, HCK, FGFR1, FMS, and others (Table 5). The binding mode of 5 in EGFR (Figure 9B, 1xkk, Table 5)(18) illustrates the opening up of the larger BP-II (BP-II-A) with a larger hydrophobic substituent that shifts the αC-helix outward in an “out” position.(18) SAR studies show a subtle preference for the optimal 3-fluorine substituent (over Br and CF3 subtituents) and the unsubstituted benzyloxy ring analogue(111) that is in line with the well-defined hydrophobic BP-II-A subpocket. Inhibitors that bind into BP-II, BP-II-A, or BP-II-b with large ring systems tend to disrupt the usually well-conserved salt bridge between KIII.17 and EαC.24 (e.g., Figure 9B, 1xkk;(18) Figure 9C, 3efk;(112) Figure 9D, 3sls(113)). Twenty-two structures contain compounds that target the deeper buried BP-II-A in DFG-in kinases, including EGFR, BRAF, ErbB2, ALK, BTK, and TIE2 (Table 5). In CDK2 (3pxz, 3py1),(114) PEK (4g31, 4g34),(115) and c-Met (2rfn,(116)3efj,(91)3efk,(91)3u6h,(117)3u6i(117)) a pocket between β sheet IV and the αC-helix is probed, designated BP-II-B. The c-Met inhibitor 35 illustrates the binding mode in which BP-II-B is reached by penetrating the gate area while binding at the hinge region (Figure 9C, 3efk, Table 5).(91) Interestingly, in MEK kinase inhibitors can bind BP-II from a MEK specific allosteric pocket that is completely separated from the ATP binding site as illustrated by 36 (UCB1353770,(113) Figure 9D, 3sls),(113) which binds into BP-II-A-in (with the iodinated phenyl ring) and BP-II-in (with the thiophene ring).

    3.3.3 Back Pocket II: DFG-out (BP-II-out)

    Comparison of the cocrystal structures of VEGFR2 naphthamide inhibitors(118)37 and 38 illustrates how differences in the size of substituents pointing toward the hydrophobic back pocket can influence the activation state of the kinase (Figure 10). While the cyclopropyl group of 37 is compatible with a DFG-in conformation and probes into BP-II-in (Figure 10A, 3b8r), the larger para-Cl phenyl ring of 38 induces VEGFR2 to assume a DFG-out conformation and probes into BP-II-out (Figure 10B, 3b8q). Our analysis identified 12 structures with compounds targeting BP-II in the DFG-out form of the kinase.
    The formation of a H-bond with the DxDFG.81 backbone NH and one or two hydrogen bonds with the side chain carboxylate of EαC.24, as shown in Figure 10, is a commonly observed hydrogen-bonding motif for DFG-out back cleft binders and involves H-bond interaction with the preserved KIII.17–EαC.24 salt bridge.

    3.3.4 Back Pockets III (BP-III), IV (BP-IV), and V (BP-V)

    Back pockets III, IV, and V are available only in the DFG-out form of the kinase. BP-III is buried behind BP-II. This pocket can be probed by DFG-out stabilizing compounds, which extend through the gate area and interact with the hinge region, as illustrated by the binding mode of the clinical candidate 39 (foretinib)(119) in c-MET (Figure 11A, 3lq8).(120) Inhibitor 39 forms hydrogen bonds with both the backbone NH atoms of DxDFG.81 and side chain of KIII.17, stabilizing the kinase DFG-out form and extending the N-(4-fluorophenyl)cyclopropanecarboxamide moiety deep into the hydrophobic back pocket III, while the cyclopropyl ring of the inhibitor is binding into BP-II-out.
    The selective PDK1 inhibitor 40 probes into BP-III with the 3,4-difluorobenzyl moiety (Figure 11B, 3nax).(121) This compound binds PDK1 in a rather unique binding mode, in which the αC-helix of PDK1 is disrupted in order to accommodate the pyridinone ring.(121) Inhibitor 6 extends into BP-II in the DFG-out form of LCK, while the piperazine ring binds in the partially hydrophobic BP-IV (Figure 11C, 2pl0).(122) The “switch-control” inhibitor 41 (rebastinib) has efficacy against the majority of relevant CML-resistance mutants and stabilizes a type II inactive conformation in ABL1 by forming a H-bond interaction with EαC.20 (Figure 11D, 3qri).(123) This residue forms an ionic interaction with R386 (not shown) and keeps ABL1 in an inactive DFG-out conformation. Inhibitor 41 binds in BP-III with its tert-butyl moiety and binds another partially hydrophobic back pocket, BP-V with its quinoline ring.
    Interestingly, the back pockets can be addressed by fragment-based design, as demonstrated for p38α. The initial fragment hit 42 (Figure 12A, DFG-in, 1w7h)(40) binds at the hinge region and probes into BP-I. This compound was merged with 43 (Figure 12B, DFG-out, 1w82),(39) which binds in BP-I, -II, -III, and -V, into 44 (Figure 12C, DFG-out, crystal structure not shown, 1wbn). Optimization of 44 led to 45 (Figure 12D, DFG-out, 1w83), which binds at the hinge and probes and binds into BP-I (central chlorophenyl ring), BP-II-out (right-most phenyl ring), BP-III (morpholino substituent on right-most phenyl ring), and BP-V (chloro substituent on right-most phenyl ring).(39) Our analysis identified 23 complexes in which the inhibitor did not bind the front cleft but solely in the gate area and back cleft probing BP-II, BP-III, and BP-V (Table 5).
    Figure 13 illustrates how the structural alignment of kinase–ligand complexes in KLIFS allows the identification of kinase inhibitor merging design strategies by analyzing the superimposed kinase ligand scaffolds described in different studies.(39, 104, 124-126) Figure 13A shows how compound 46 binds the hinge and back pockets BP-I-A and BP-I-B of p38 (1wbw),(39) while compound 47 binds back pockets BP-I-B, BP-II-out, and BP-III but does not interact with adenine pocket AP (3o8u).(124)
    Both 46 (IC50 = 44 μM) and 47 (IC50 = 17–21 μM)(126) inhibit p38 with moderate potency. Inhibitor 48 (DP-437,(126)3nnv)(126) shares the naphthalene scaffold of 46 and the tert-butylpyrazoleurea scaffold of 47 that maintain conserved binding modes in back pockets BP-I-A/BP-I-A and BP-III, respectively (Figure 13B). Compound 48 further extends into BP-V with a hydroxymethylphenyl group and has a significantly higher potency for p38 (IC50 = 27 nM) than 46 and 47.(126) Figure 13C shows how 49 (BIRB 796,(104)1kv2)(104) covers all binding pockets occupied by compounds 46, 47, and 48 and combines a naphthalene (shared with 46 and 48), tert-butylpyrazoleurea (shared with 47 and 48), and a substituted phenyl group (shared with 48) with a morpholino group that targets the hinge in the adenosine pocket (like 46). Binding kinetics studies indicate that 49 has a 1700-fold slower dissociation rate (koff = 8.3 × 10–6) than 47 (koff = 1.4 × 10–1) and a significantly higher potency (IC50 = 8–97 nM, depending on assay preincubation time).(104) This structure–kinetics relationship (SKR) suggests that targeting back pockets BP-II/III/V in combination with the AP pocket (including the hinge) can be an attractive strategy to design kinase inhibitors with improved residence time.

    3.3.5 Covalent Binders of Kinases

    Irreversible binding of a ligand to a specific target can be used to substantially decrease the off-rate from the target and maintain a longer effect. Systematic search for covalent binders identified 12 kinase crystal structures in which a ligand links to a cysteine residue (in all cases included in the 85 kinase–ligand binding site residues) of EGFR (2j5f,(127)2jiv,(128) and 3ika(129)), ErbB4 (2r4b(130)), ITK (3t9t,(131)4hcu, 4hcv, and 4hct(132)), JNK3 (3v6r and 3v6s(133)), PDK1 (3pwy(134)), and RSK-2 (4d9u(135)). In the cases mentioned above, the inhibitors covalently bind to a cysteine residue at position aaII.11 (RSK-2), aalinker.52 (EGFR, ErbB4, ITK, and PDK1), or aaαD.54 (JNK3).

    4 Ligand Scaffold Requirements To Bind Kinase Subpockets

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Table 6 gives an overview of representative scaffolds that bind in the different areas and subpockets of the kinase catalytic cleft. The requirements of the different groups are area and subpocket specific and give insights into the kinase ligand design toolkit. This toolkit can be used as a recipe for the design of novel kinase ligands. At the solvent exposed part, where inhibitors exit the kinase via the “linker” region in the proteins, a variety of polar substituents are found. Typical substituents are morpholines or piperazines. In the adenosine pocket, flat aromatic heterocycles are the majority of scaffolds found to bind at the hinge region. Usually one hydrogen bond acceptor is present, in addition to one or two hydrogen-bond donors. In FP-I hydrophobic interactions are made with apolar moieties like substituted phenyl or piperidine rings. FP-II can be targeted with apolar or polar structures, e.g., halogenated phenyl rings or nitriles. BP-I-A is often targeted by hydrophobic ortho substituents (e.g., methyl groups and halogens) on phenyl rings. However, depending on the kinase type, BP-I-A can accommodate larger substituents, like phenyl or naphthalene rings. In a DFG-in kinase, BP-II is rather small and is typically probed with smaller, hydrophobic substituents. Hydrogen bonding with EαC.24 is possible by the addition of hydrogen bond donors (e.g., hydroxyl groups) to the substituents. BP-II-A and -B in the DFG-in kinase can accommodate larger moieties, like halogenated phenyl rings. A typical feature of BP-II-A probing substituents is the presence of a linker, which enables the sharp turn needed to reach this pocket after entering the gate area. BP-III is targeted by large groups, like tert-butyl groups but also morpholines. The partially hydrophobic back pockets IV and V are solvent exposed and can be targeted with groups like methylpiperazines and morpholines. The current KLIFS kinase–ligand structure-based analysis is complementary to ligand (kinase affinity profile) based analyses,(38, 47, 136) as KLIFS identifies the molecular determinants of kinase affinity and selectivity and gives explicit insights into the binding modes and interactions of chemical scaffolds of ligands in kinase binding sites.
    Table 6. Analysis of Scaffold Types in the Different Areas of the Catalytic Cleft
    Table a

    See Figure 2 for an overview of different regions in kinase binding site.

    Table b

    General description of scaffold type.

    Table c

    Predominant pharmacophoric element: HBA (H-bond acceptor), HBD (H-bond donor), HYD (hydrophobic).

    Table d

    Examples of scaffolds representing the general description and predominant pharmacophoric element.

    5 DFG-Motif Conformation and α-Helix C Position

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    For all ligand bound structures, the conformation of the DFG-motif was determined and structures were divided into three main groups: DFG-in, -out-like, and -out (see Supporting Information). In the DFG-in conformation, the DxDFG.81 side chain is oriented toward the ATP binding site while the FxDFG.82 side chain is located in the back cleft (see Figure 5A). In the DFG-out conformation, this orientation is flipped 180° and the backbone is shifted toward the ATP binding site, thereby enlarging the volume of the back cleft and presenting the DFG-out FxDFG.82 residue as part of the BP-I-B pocket (see Figure 5D). For the DFG-out-like conformation, multiple modes exist. In Figure 6D, the DFG-motif is flipped 180° compared to a DFG-in form; however, the backbone is not shifted toward ATP binding site and the back cleft is not accessible. Structures in which the side chains of DxDFG.81 and FxDFG.82 both point toward the back cleft and others exist. Table 7 gives an overview of the number of structures and the status of the DFG-motif.
    Table 7. Status of the DFG-Motif Conformation and Position of α-Helix C
      structures
    structural elementastatus% structuresno. structures
    DFG-motifin851061
     out-like566
     out10121
     nab<14
    αCin55690
     out-like11142
     out33418
     nab<12
    a

    Location DFG-motif and α-helix C are indicated in Figure 2.

    b

    na = The status of this structural element could not be determined.

    To determine the position of the αC-helix, we measured the distance between the Cα carbon atoms of DxDFG.81 and EαC.24 (See Supporting Information). This resulted in the identification of two main clusters of distances between the DFG-motif and the αC-helix. Structures with a short DFG-αC-helix distance (4–7.2 Å) were marked αC-in, while structures with long distance (9.3–14 Å) were marked as αC-out. Structures with distances in between these clusters were marked as αC-out-like structures. In Table 7, an overview of the number of structures, the DFG conformation, and the position of the αC-helix is presented.

    6 Possible Applications of KLIFS in Kinase Ligand Discovery and Design

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The KLIFS database offers insights into the structural requirements of kinase binding that will be useful in future structure-based ligand discovery and design studies. Examples of possible applications are the following:
    (i) Definition of protein–ligand constraints and postprocessing rules to drive virtual screening campaigns for the discovery of new kinase ligands.(137) Exclusion of docking poses that do not form specific hinge H-bond interactions has, for example, been shown to minimize false positives in retrospective virtual screening experiments against multiple kinase crystal structures.(138) Moreover, protein–ligand interaction fingerprint scoring approaches (based on binding mode similarity to known kinase–ligand cocrystal structures) have been shown to be superior to standard docking scoring functions in retrospective kinase structure-based virtual screening studies.(51, 64) Also in prospective virtual screening studies, H-bond constraints have, for example, been successfully used to filter docking simulations to identify novel EphA4 inhibiting fragments.(139)
    (ii) Design of new chemical groups that can accommodate the same interactions with the kinase binding site (scaffold hopping).(34, 53, 140)
    (iii) Guiding of ligand optimization, e.g., where to place specific polar or hydrophobic group in the optimization of known (or new) kinase ligand scaffolds. An interesting approach is fragment-based drug discovery, for example, as demonstrated for PKB (Figure 7)(41) and p38 (Figure 12 and Figure 13).(39, 104, 124-126) The examples illustrate that different pockets can be addressed by different fragment-based drug discovery strategies, either by growing out the initial fragment into a hydrophobic front pocket (as demonstrated for FP-II, Figure 7)(41) or by merging overlapping fragments (Figure 12 and Figure 13).(39, 104, 125, 126)
    (iv) Offer new insights into kinase selectivity by linking ligand and kinase properties.(45) Several chemogenomic/proteochemometric models combining ligand and residue information of kinases have been constructed and, for example, applied to (retrospectively) predict kinase selectivity profiles.(47, 53, 141) Retrospective studies have shown that classification of kinases by structure-based alignment of their ligand binding site is feasible.(46, 142, 143) Incorporation of more detailed structure-based information regarding (selective) kinase–ligand interactions in such chemogenomic studies could therefore be an interesting approach for future kinome wide in silico ligand-profiling studies. In this way KLIFS will offer a knowledge-based chemogenomics platform that can help to overcome problems in kinase drug discovery associated with crowded IP space(144, 145) (Figure 1) and kinase selectivity in the future.

    7 Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Cross family ligand binding features were studied in a thorough analysis of kinase–ligand interaction patterns, covering all regions of the catalytic site of all currently available human kinase crystal structures. A database of 1252 aligned human kinase–ligand cocrystal structures present in the Protein Data Bank (PDB) has been constructed, and the different kinase–ligand interaction features were mapped by using molecular interaction fingerprints (KLIFS, periodically updated and accessible on the Web at http://www.vu-compmedchem.nl). Identification of family- or group-specific interaction features and classification of ligands according to their binding modes was possible by using a consistent alignment and numbering of the 85 kinase ligand binding site residues. Novel insights into how conserved and selective kinase interaction hot spots can accommodate the large diversity of chemical scaffolds observed in kinase ligands are presented by systematic mining of kinase–ligand interaction space. Requirements for ligand scaffolds to bind kinase subpockets are presented. These studies lead to an improved understanding of the structural requirements of kinase binding that will be useful in future ligand discovery and design studies.

    Supporting Information

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    2D structures of compounds that are not presented in other figures, a list of crystal structures of approved kinase inhibitors in the PDB, a table of all crystal structures used for the structural reference alignment, and the methodology of the KLIFS database preparation and analysis, including description of PDB collection, kinase domain sequence alignment, pocket selection, database creation, IFP generation, and DFG and αC-helix classification. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org. The KLIFS database is periodically updated and accessible on the Web at http://www.vu-compmedchem.nl, including all structure files and corresponding annotations.

      Targeting cancer with small molecule kinase inhibitors
      Zhang, Jianming; Yang, Priscilla L.; Gray, Nathanael S.
      Nature Reviews Cancer (2009), 9 (1), 28-39CODEN: NRCAC4; ISSN:1474-175X. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Deregulation of kinase activity has emerged as a major mechanism by which cancer cells evade normal physiol. constraints on growth and survival. To date, 11 kinase inhibitors have received US Food and Drug Administration approval as cancer treatments, and there are considerable efforts to develop selective small mol. inhibitors for a host of other kinases that are implicated in cancer and other diseases. Herein we discuss the current challenges in the field, such as designing selective inhibitors and developing strategies to overcome resistance mutations. This Review provides a broad overview of some of the approaches currently used to discover and characterize new kinase inhibitors.

      The (un)targeted cancer kinome
      Fedorov, Oleg; Mueller, Susanne; Knapp, Stefan
      Nature Chemical Biology (2010), 6 (3), 166-169CODEN: NCBABT; ISSN:1552-4450. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review and discussion. The complexity of cancer signaling and the resulting difficulties in target selection have strongly biased kinase drug discovery towards clin. validated targets. Recently, novel kinase targets that are uncharacterized have emerged from genome sequencing and RNAi studies. Chem. probes are urgently needed to functionally annotate these kinases and to stimulate new drug discovery efforts.

    5. 5
      Manning, G.; Whyte, D. B.; Martinez, R.; Hunter, T.; Sudarsanam, S. The protein kinase complement of the human genome Science 2002, 298, 1912– 1934
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      The Protein Kinase Complement of the Human Genome
      Manning, G.; Whyte, D. B.; Martinez, R.; Hunter, T.; Sudarsanam, S.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2002), 298 (5600), 1912-1916, 1933-1934CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      We have catalogued the protein kinase complement of the human genome (the "kinome") using public and proprietary genomic, complementary DNA, and expressed sequence tag (EST) sequences. This provides a starting point for comprehensive anal. of protein phosphorylation in normal and disease states, as well as a detailed view of the current state of human genome anal. through a focus on one large gene family. We identify 518 putative protein kinase genes, of which 71 have not previously been reported or described as kinases, and we extend or correct the protein sequences of 56 more kinases. New genes include members of well-studied families as well as previously unidentified families, some of which are conserved in model organisms. Classification and comparison with model organism kinomes identified orthologous groups and highlighted expansions specific to human and other lineages. We also identified 106 protein kinase pseudogenes. Chromosomal mapping revealed several small clusters of kinase genes and revealed that 244 kinases map to disease loci or cancer amplicons.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xpt1Wisb0%253D&md5=b3def83bace52257a3252a3347b8bb92

      Chico, L. K.; Van Eldik, L. J.; Watterson, D. M. Targeting protein kinases in central nervous system disorders Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2009, 8, 892– 909

      Targeting protein kinases in central nervous system disorders
      Chico, Laura K.; Van Eldik, Linda J.; Watterson, D. Martin
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2009), 8 (11), 892-909CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Protein kinases are a growing drug target class in disorders in peripheral tissues, but the development of kinase-targeted therapies for central nervous system (CNS) diseases remains a challenge, largely owing to issues assocd. specifically with CNS drug discovery. However, several candidate therapeutics that target CNS protein kinases are now in various stages of preclin. and clin. development. We review candidate compds. and discuss selected CNS protein kinases that are emerging as important therapeutic targets. In addn., we analyze trends in small-mol. properties that correlate with key challenges in CNS drug discovery, such as blood-brain barrier penetrance and cytochrome P 450-mediated metab., and discuss the potential of future approaches that will integrate mol.-fragment expansion with pharmacoinformatics to address these challenges.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtlCjtrzO&md5=4dc1f6b7542e59c99f91525d37c49973

      Cohen, P. Targeting protein kinases for the development of anti-inflammatory drugs Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 2009, 21, 317– 324
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Targeting protein kinases for the development of anti-inflammatory drugs
      Cohen, Philip
      Current Opinion in Cell Biology (2009), 21 (2), 317-324CODEN: COCBE3; ISSN:0955-0674. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. In recent years, protein kinases have become the pharmaceutical industry's most studied class of drug target, and some 10 protein kinase inhibitors have so far been approved for the treatment of cancer. However, whether safe drugs that modulate protein kinase activities can also be developed for the treatment of chronic diseases, where they may need to be taken for decades, is an issue that is still unresolved. A no. of compds. that inhibit the p38α MAPK have entered clin. trials for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and psoriasis, but side effects have prevented their progression to Phase III clin. trials. Here the author briefly reviews the potential problems in targeting p38 MAPK and discusses other protein kinases that regulate the innate immune system, such as Tpl2, MAPKAP-K2/3, MSK1/2, and IRAK4, which may be better targets for the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, and NIK, which is an attractive target for the treatment of multiple myeloma, a late stage B-cell malignancy.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXksVCksrg%253D&md5=b7e7a33f18d0c8c1e33160c092cf411b
    9. 9
      Kumar, R.; Singh, V. P.; Baker, K. M. Kinase inhibitors for cardiovascular disease J. Mol. Cell. Cardiol. 2007, 42, 1– 11
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Kinase inhibitors for cardiovascular disease
      Kumar, Rajesh; Singh, Vivek P.; Baker, Kenneth M.
      Journal of Molecular and Cellular Cardiology (2007), 42 (1), 1-11CODEN: JMCDAY; ISSN:0022-2828. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A review. Over the last decade, there was substantial progress toward understanding the pathophysiol. and treatment of cardiovascular diseases (CVDs). Elucidating cellular responses to the extracellular environment and signal transduction mechanisms have provided the opportunity to explore novel mol. therapeutic approaches for the treatment of CVDs. Neurohormonal stimulation was implicated in these diseases; blockade of the renin-angiotensin and β-adrenergic systems are examples of therapeutic effectiveness. There are multiple cell signaling cascades, some of which are beneficial or compensatory and others deleterious. The balance between these pathways, which in large part is dictated by the cellular environment, dets. the outcome as a diseased or non-diseased state. Selective targeting of signaling pathways using protein kinase inhibitors, would have a potential advantage over receptor blockers. We review potential protein kinase targets and recent evidence supporting therapeutic interventional value in CVDs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXht1Cnuw%253D%253D&md5=8b05f4f7c07fb4b704089caeee02e7c3

      Doerig, C.; Billker, O.; Pratt, D.; Endicott, J. Protein kinases as targets for antimalarial intervention: kinomics, structure-based design, transmission-blockade, and targeting host cell enzymes Biochim. Biophys. Acta, Proteins Proteomics 2005, 1754, 132– 150
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Protein kinases as targets for antimalarial intervention: Kinomics, structure-based design, transmission-blockade, and targeting host cell enzymes
      Doerig, Christian; Billker, Oliver; Pratt, David; Endicott, Jane
      Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, Proteins and Proteomics (2005), 1754 (1-2), 132-150CODEN: BBAPBW; ISSN:1570-9639. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. The surge of interest in protein kinases as targets for chemotherapeutic intervention in a no. of diseases such as cancer and neurodegenerative disorders has stimulated research aimed at detg. whether enzymes of this class might also be considered as targets in the context of diseases caused by parasitic protists. Here, we present an overview of recent developments in this field, concg. (i) on the benefits gained from the availability of genomic databases for a no. of parasitic protozoa, (ii) on the emerging field of structure-aided design of inhibitors targeting protein kinases of parasitic protists, (iii) on the concept known as transmission-blockade, whereby kinases implicated in the development of the parasite in their arthropod vector might be targeted to interfere with disease transmission, and (iv) on the possibility of controlling parasitic diseases through the inhibition of host cell protein kinases that are required for the establishment of infection by the parasites.
